In September renewed clashes broke out in southern Karen state between the military and rebels. The northern half of the western state of Rakhine is currently under a military lockdown after a string of deadly attacks against border posts last month. More than 30,000 people have been displaced and at least 70 people killed in the latest fighting in Rakhine. Myanmar's military has a long history of rights abuses that has fostered a deep mistrust among ethnic minorities of the central government. Suu Kyi also has limited control over the army which retains 25% of parliamentary seats as well as key defence and security positions in government.

Thousands Flee Crackdown in Myanmar's Rakhine State (from the October 14, 2016 Daily News Brief, Council on Foreign Relations [dailybrief@e.cfr.org]) Thousands of people are fleeing (AFP) the northern state of Rakhine in Myanmar as the military torched villages searching for the perpetrators of attacks that killed nine officers (NYT) amid concerns of a resurgence in communal violence. Army helicopters evacuated teachers and public servants from the villages at the heart of the hostilities (RFA). State media has reported that forty-three people, including thirteen security agents, have been killed (Myanmar Times). State Counselor Aung San Suu Kyi said in a press conference this week that she would wait for a government team to return from the region this weekend before commenting on the situation (RFA). In 2012, clashes in Rakhine state between Buddhists and Muslims killed more than a hundred people and displaced tens of thousands.

A good sign http://aa.com.tr/en/asia-pacific/myanmar-troops-jailed-for-civilian-deaths-in-rare-move/646922 "A court-martial in Myanmar has sentenced seven soldiers to five years in jail for murdering civilians in northeastern Shan State during fighting with ethnic rebels, an army-run newspaper reported Friday. Four officers and three lower-ranking soldiers from the Northeast Command based in Lashio Township of restive Shan have admitted to murdering the five villagers during clashes June 25, according to the military-owned Myawaddy." However, EWP's Expert Opinion Pool has been at 10% for the past several months and I can't see why. http://www.acleddata.com/asia-data/ and the Myanmar files don't seem to have many non-combatant civilian deaths recorded (though I've only skimmed the figures there).

(no change for now) I’ve resigned myself to NOT getting any further clarification from EWP on what constitutes a mass killing. (Consequently, I’ve not elected to join the more recent questions.) Looking at part of the EWP definitions, I’d like to offer an opinion about two points related to this phrase: “targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less” 1. I now believe (but wouldn’t be surprised if EWP made a clarification that contradicted this) that the period related to any specific question starts when the question is introduced and runs through the end of CY 2016. (I believe the other ideas that it either looks back in a running period of a year or is the whole calendar year are wrong.) 2. There are at least two interpretations of which group(s) are targeted. A narrow interpretation is that whatever government (“in” tribe) forces there are target only a specific subset of the population. Then there is a broader interpretation that any significant deaths that are not combat related or otherwise proscribed would count (in the sense that those targeted are “outsiders” in some sense). I lean now toward accepting either, but probably put less weight on the latter as I think about a particular situation.
Down 2% to be closer to consensus.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

(no change) Two links to help clarify things until either GJO or @EarlyWarningProject can provide more global clarification regarding the relevant time frame(s). First is EWP’s answer on the GJO questions: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/281886 One can either interpret it to mean the clock started when the question opened or try to parse this quote “over the course of the year, without regard to calendar year.” Second is the web page for the EWP expert opinion pool: http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools (As you will note, the latter is for a calendar year. EWP tries to be clear that there are differences between the Expert Opinion Pool criteria and the GJO questions.) I’m updating my “understanding” so that I can find it easily and don’t have to guess: 1. The time frame for this episode begins on 2 February 2016 and ends on 31 December 2016. (Please feel free to explain the unexplainable.)

(no change) Here is one link I've relied on to confirm that the EWP questions are for the full calendar year 2016: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/244986 I interpret this as confirming that it is for a full calendar year (if not otherwise specified).

Up 2%. Don't really know where to go with this as evidence is mounting that passive genocide is a very real possibility. We've already seen forced relocation and ghettoization of the Rohingya (there, I said it); now we're up to the denial of identity, deprivation and deportation stage. There's something awfully familiar about this. Big question is whether EWP will register a mass killing if these people are simply allowed to die of preventable diseases or are left with no option but a dangerous escape.
Raising 2% as US insistence on naming the Rohingya may fan nationalistic aggression.
Updating for passage of time, lack of obvious friction between new government and military.

EPW's Expert Opinion pool is relatively high at 10%, compared to GJOpen's consensus of 5%. I'm reducing slightly from my 5% of last month because there has been no indication of brewing mass killings under the new regime, which is probably trying to bring all parties together for talks under the democratic umbrella.

Yet, it is in the nature of the respective government to just say, "Oh yeah, did you hear about that? Crazy, how nationalist can get so upset over SEPARATISTS?" On a good way to become a democratic state. History wise Myanmar has a huge potential to become a powerful player in their geographic area.

What now for Myanmar? Is Aung Sun Suu Kyi becoming a 'democratic dictator'
http://www.smh.com.au/world/what-now-for-myanmar-is-aung-sun-suu-kyi-becoming-a-democratic-dictator-20160331-gnuxdo.html "The military blocked Suu Kyi from becoming president and retained a quarter of seats in parliament. It also gets to appoint four key defence and security ministers, installed a hardline general as senior vice-president and, only days before the government was sworn in, delivered a blunt message that it remains in charge.
 'The Tatmadaw [military] has to be present as the leading role in national politics with regards to the ways we stand along the history and critical situations of the country," senior general Min Aung Hlaing told 10,000 troops on a parade ground in the capital Naypyitaw, adding that a lack of rule of law and armed insurgencies "could lead to chaotic democracy' .
"Under the constitution, the army chief can take over in times of crisis.
Suu Kyi was notably absent from the parade on Armed Forces Day, the most important event on the military's calendar, and has not responded publicly to the remarks.
And General Min Aung Hlaing has made clear in recent days he won't deal directly with Suu Kyi and will communicate only with the president."
Durch den demokratischen Prozess der eingesetzt hat sowie weiteren Faktoren wir oben genannter Fall nicht eintreten.
It seems like electoral politics, in some form, is taking hold in Myanmar.
After Myanmar elections with populist 'non-president' Aung Suu Kyi the State is looking far more stable as it moves to economic development, which would be severely hindered by Rohinga genocide.

There are many armed groups and a low level civil war in several regions. The army has given up (some) control, but could feel forced to step back in. The rohingya will continue to suffer, and they may become pawns in a battle between the army and the elected govt
I just cannot see it. so I go up to 5 no hedgehawg on EWP limited application  of strategy and public policy considerations.

A major concern is the friction that is emerging between ethnic groups. The fighting between TNLA and RCSS in Northern Shan State is raising the acrimony between Shan and Palaung ethnic groups. The peace dialogue will probably exacerbate the divisions between signatories and non-signatories of the National Ceasefire Agreement and between bigger and smaller ethnic groups. This could be further fueled by the release of the Census data on ethnicity and religion. The recent election of U Htin Kyaw as president shows Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's extra self-confidence and willingness to hold control over all decisions and her resistance in delegating power. The challenges ahead would require a much higher degree of inclusion in decision making that can actually be a threat. There is concern and understanding among the international community of these challenges and this might mitigate the risk, which is anyway high at 66%.

Conflict and powerful companies stoke land disputes in Myanmar's Kachin
http://www.reuters.com/article/myanmar-land-idUSL8N1622WY
Changes in land ownership and use are among key issues in Myanmar's political and economic transition, with deep resentment and protests over acquisitions for infrastructure, development or large-scale agricultural projects.Up to 70 percent of Myanmar's labour force is estimated to work in agriculture. The sector accounts for 44 percent of economic output, according to consulting firm McKinsey & Co.  All land is owned by the government but farmers are given land use or tillage rights, making land use a particularly sensitive issue for small-scale farmers who make up the majority of the country's population of 51 million. Yet these rights are neither respected on the ground in practice, nor provide protection against land grabbing, activists said.

Crowd view is correct. I had marked up originally as I believed that the delay between the election and a NLD leader being installed  as President could result in several  scenarios that are  thought in the political science literature  to increase the likelihood  of xenophobic and repressive genocide,
I am assuming that NLD has an even stronger commitment to  detecting and preventing genocide, The issue for the incoming government, there is no central government.
Trek through the Shan state on the border of Thailand.
Central government? none other than military command. and in Shan state very few soldiers.
Except those mining and trading in precious gems. So I am joining crowd. Until now Burma ( yes I know that term is incorrect) was more of a collection of ethnic wars.
I call it Burma as it never existed as a nation state. Caught between India and Thais.
It was not even a British colony until Winston Churchill's father Lord Randolph Churchill  urged annexation to the BE  it as a "birthday  present" to Queen Victoria. Whether or not, the NLD will be able to forge a  nation state out of " Burma" I am unsure just how much control  the central government has in the far West of country.
But the Early Warning Site and others  list numerous ngos on the ground. I am reviewing all the questions on  this challenge.

Not likely especially after the election in 2015. After series of bloody conflicts in past years, the public is very much aware of how such communal violence could be detrimental to their community and their aspiration for democracy and freedom.
With peaceful democratic elections, Myanmar is now becoming a more open, democratic society.
Seems like transition relatively smooth - hopeful sign.

Trimming to 9 percent on signs that the NLD and military will be able to cohabitate in government for a while. This lowers the risk of a state-led mass killing as part of a reactionary coup or in response to protest activity that might have occurred if the military had blocked the NLD from taking power, and I think those were the main pathways by which this event might have occurred this year.

Political stability and general situation looks OK-ish compared to past, and economic situation is still improving, but it's fragile depending on external global economy, weather and internal tensions. Rohingya in Rakhine and MNDCAA in Kokang could be potential areas of more conflict. Though recent desire for international engagement and enrichment could counter any mass killing being too large or open.
ISIS is recruiting there so mass killings may be reversed to protect Rohingya Muslims

>What drives mass killings in underdeveloped countries, in general? According to the genocide watch, there are 7 factors (http://genocidewatch.net/2014/05/01/why-do-people-commit-genocide-and-what-can-we-do-to-prevent-it-by-gregory-h-stanton/): a. country being engaged in recent civil war (check - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myanmar#Civil_wars) b. country has been exposed to recent genocides (check- Still open to research, but a mass killings event happened more than thrice in 10 years, so it is very frequent if compared to a first world country.
Last killing episode in 2015 - "Armed conflict between ethnic Chinese rebels and the Myanmar Armed Forces have resulted in the Kokang offensive in February 2015. The conflict had forced 40,000 to 50,000 civilians to flee their homes and seek shelter on the Chinese side of the border." ) c. country governed by an exclusively ethnical elite (not at the moment, since 68% of the population matches the government ethnic group - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_in_Myanmar) d. Ruling party has an exclusionary ideology, such as nazism (no, the recently elected NLD party preaches non-violent approaches https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_for_Democracy#Party_platform) e. Is the regime totalitarian? (not entirely, as explicit above, but there is high military influence, so I would consider it a hazard point) f. Closure to relations with outside world (no - has relations with many EU countries, China and India + is a part of ASEAN - http://madb.europa.eu/madb/statistical_form.htm) g. Massive violations to human rights (check - there were a few in recent years, see wikipedia article) In general, it is expected that, with the change in their regime, the human rights violations and mass killings trend gets diluted.
However, I would assume that there is still a considerable risk of turmoil, as the country is still under heavy millitary influence.
Military leaders will want to retain what public support it already has.
The political establishment's lack of commitment to equality before the law will continue to keep the violence between Buddhists and the Muslim's on the forefront.

Myanmar is in the midst of a movement toward a less authoritative government to a more open economic model. Often there is a a little chaos in a move like this,,,, Those that can't have control will create chaos. This chaos will be used to try and take control and many extremist groups will hit conditions like this as they move toward a more modern western type life.
Myanmar is trying very hard to become a civilized country, encourage tourism, foreign investment and trade. They'll do everything they can do maintain civil order.

With the transition from military rule to electoral rule (using the term because of the tentative nature of politics in Myanmar) and the election of a President within the next 10 days or so, the risk of mass killings or genocide on the part of the new government is somewhat low;  their is no record of how the new government would respond to or react to engagement by or among various rebel groups against the current direction of the country.  Since their such a large amount of uncertainty including limited open reporting of political activity in the country, it is always possible, however at present, with a low degree of such a possibility.

Newly formed, unstable democracy;
Global warming induced natural disaster (flooding) likely, causing upheaval and competition for resources. 
Military junta will feel insecure, want to reestablish power, will target democratic proponents; and/or radical Buddhist monks will target vulnerable "infidel" populations.
At risk group: Rohingya refugees.

Focus in Myanmar is on a peaceful handover to an elected civilian government (albeit "guided" by the military). Affirming my forecast from last month, and noting that EWP's expert opinion poll is also at 10% http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools/106

My main concern is with something flaring up before the new government takes over -- they won't end the possibility of a mass killing, but they should lower the probability. There's a chance that more than 1000 could die anyway under the "starvation/medical deprivation" definition -- maybe they've already hit 1000 -- but I don't know if that will be easy to uncover or to count in time. Adjusting upward slightly to match my new focus on nonviolent "killings".
Buddhist monks is unpredictable this will vary on there individual principles that will push them to initiate it or it can be coming from politically motivated

BBC reported on  25 Feb. that there were clashes erupting in Northern Myanmar over opium poppy fields. With a weak economic backbone and a relatively diverse ethnic background, despite the fact that Myanmar has trying to induce democracy, it would be extremely difficult to maneuver it. Even if the regime has a strong aspiration for a solid political platform, there are higher chances of them resorting to violence against ethnic groups in the form of ethnic cleansing in order to stabilize Myanmar.
The situation is still largely unstable

With information being very scarce and with a lot of it reliant on refugee hearsay, I don't see high odds for any provable (at least in time for the deadline) deaths above the 1k additional threshold as defined on this site.  While the odds are said to be increased, it is hard to parse out the activism vs. ultimate reality here. 5% is still high odds if it were my own neighborhood, but viewed vs. higher-hazard areas like the Congo, this area doesn't seem likely to hit the definition in the next 11 months barring extreme events snowballing.

"Despite continued government restrictions, some Rohingya had not left because they were holding out hope for the new government led by Aung San Suu Kyi’s NLD, said Smith of Fortify Rights. “Many Muslims in Rakhine State tell us they hope Daw Suu will usher in a better day for them. Anything, they say, will be better than the past,” he said. (http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/news/heavy-price-to-pay-for-freedom-1988897) "And, above all, the oppression of the 1 million Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar should cease. It would be unconscionable for this new government, with or without Suu Kyi as president, to continue disenfranchising the Rohingya and relegating so many of them to squalid refugee camps."
(http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2016/02/197_198885.html) "The Rohingya issue and anti-Muslim sentiment in Myanmar pose real problems, but this claim is largely exaggerated. Critics of Myanmar on this issue in particular tend to forget that the growing anti-Muslim sentiment is a challenge shared in many countries across the globe - with the refugee crisis in Europe, and the rise of Trump-ism in the United States, all of which share entrenched societal xenophobic and racist sentiments. Since the Rakhine State riots in 2012, the paramilitary movement in Myanmar has lessened. The NLD earlier this month openly condemned Buddhist extremist groups such as Mabatha and the 969 movement, a commendable approach that will be reflective in its policies and legislation, moving forward. At the root of the problem, as Suu Kyi has repeatedly explained to the international community, is the issue of Rule of Law and proper enforcement. Acts of aggression have been committed on both sides, and the situation of Muslims in Myanmar, though deplorable, does not constitute genocide. Additionally, transforming the ways people view Muslims is inherently difficult, a problem the United States knows all too well, and is not limited to Buddhist nationalist groups and paramilitary organizations. Tolerance and acceptance are values that must grow organically to spread throughout the country." (http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jack-myint/a-myanmar-perspective-on-rebalance_b_9274826.html) "Earlier also, she has displayed a tendency for choosing expediency over principle. For example, she refused to speak against the persecution of the Muslim Rohingyas during the election campaign and to field any Rohingya candidate. This was to appease the Buddhist 969 Movement, led by a group of fanatical and bigoted monks, even though such a stand was against all norms of justice." (http://saudigazette.com.sa/opinion/editorial/choices-before-suu-kyi/)

As a base probability I would say that in the 5 last years there was roughly an episode of serious violence/ mass killing against Muslims every 2 years (riots in 2011, 2012 and 2014 see  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims_in_Myanmar) so my base probability would be 50%. This is a problem based on Budhist anti-Muslim feelings. And sadly not even Sun Yiu's NLD has been fighting those feelings. Since, this state of affairs is not likely to change anytime soon, the only way to lower the YES is the passage of time. I will lower the forecast as the 1st January 2017 approaches.
But, like Ethiopia, unlikely to be reported fully.
Sadly, I expect a far greater chance of increased mass killing (by current forces and others yet to begin) than I do of civility and peace among citizens.
With the regime being secretive than before, we can state that their may be chances of mass killings being higher.

In the transition from a military run nation to the beginnings of an elected government there will be challenges to power centers.  New boundaries will need to be set delineating how much and which powers will be allowed to leave the control of the military.  Generally it is force which will set those boundaries.  The challenge will come from those who will have the most to gain and that very same group will be those to whom the military lease want to have new or additional power.   The result will conflict leading to large scale loss of life.
(no change) Interesting article, including "ethnic minorities that make up 40 percent of the population:" http://macaudailytimes.com.mo/myanmar-insurgents-fight-on-despite-advent-of-democracy.html

It seems unlikely that after such a lengthy transition process the military will be interested in a crackdown. As the military has been the oppressive organization against other groups, it seems unlikely they would risk the transition for any grievances that might interrupt the democratization process in the near term. History of violence an unrest means that some groups might unexpectedly conduct such attacks for various grievances
The track record of this country.

increasing my forecast by 5%. A new president is coming in, and the holdover CIC has his term renewed for five years. He is already 60 yo and theoretically should be forced to retire. Given the ongoing talks with the new president this seems like a strong move, and slightly increases the risk of breakdown, in which case the CIC may cause some military troubles. The military, after all, is guaranteed political seats and is an independent political party for now.
The Buddhists of Myanmar regard themselves as the last line of defence against Islamic invaders - extremely high chance of another mass killing

New government will result in the people having some hope
There's a lot of tension but no mass killing in 2016
Initial forecast, primary influences:  reading sources in Khalid's Feb 3 forecast and a link that I lost suggesting less chances after an election
Myanmar moving towards democracy will help not having mass killings
Almost a year out. I am going to say low chance on this one.
With elections coming up, tempers will be high.

Rohingya are a Muslim minority in a country of oppressed minority groups used to violence and ethnic cleansing. While the NLD's new majority in office will help to curb outbreaks toward Karen and other Burmese groups this sub group may likely be at more risk to violence from more than just state groups as they are also a religious minority. Thus according to the definition on this question, it's likely that between state groups and others in a culture used to this kind of treatment of minority groups, reaching 1,000 deaths by January 1, 2017 is a real possibility. By definition on this question taking into consideration threats from state and non-state groups 1,000 deaths is not that hard to reach unfortunately.

Violence against the muslim minority has occured several times in the last 100 years, but the most recent flair up of violence led by the 969 movement in 2013 only led to the death of about 300 muslims according to the website genocide watch. Indeed the murder rate is quite high (>8000 in 2012), but much of this seems to be driven by the large drug trade and lesser based on racial cleansing. Even reports I have red by the Wirathu, the leader of 969 seem not to encourage violence predominantly, but rather seem concerned with the political issue of whether these people should be granted citizenship. The recent election of a more moderate government, with the massive defeat of the anti-islamic coalition seem to suggest that people disagree with the more extreme views of this party. Deaths at the rates exceeding the amount defined here (1000) seem to have not happened here since the 1930s, and thus it seems somewhat unlikely that it would occur in the next year, barring some unforeseen act of violence by a muslim against a buddhist (seems the 2013 case was brought about the supposed rape of a buddhist woman by 3 muslim men). Need to do more research about the rates of anti-muslim murders by similar neighboring buddhist majority countries like Thailand.

I'm reconsidering my earlier forecast, which effectively rejected the Early Warning Project's 2015 statistical risk assessment and focused on the base rate, and starting over. This time, I'm accepting that statistical forecast as the best current estimate of the risk of a state-led mass killing and then adding my best guess at the base-rate risk of non-state mass killing (1 percent) to it to get to 14 percent. I will adjust that number downward for passage of time and would probably move it upward in response to coup attempts, escalations of any kind of violent rebellion, the onset of a major nonviolent campaign, or evidence of violence that meets the project's criteria for mass killing.

The definition of Mass Killing is specific, deliberate killing of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less. There are reasons for the specificity and they are sound, the idea is to identify killings leading to genocidal events and other deliberate targeting activities. Because of the nature of the Myanmar violence the current threat is low. However, the ethnic minority can become a target of violence swiftly as the coals generally simmer beneath the surface. Yet, it is doubtful that it would reach the 1000 mark with the current liberalization movement underway.

Even though things are getting better in Myanmar, I think the chances of mass killing doesn't necessarily decrease. So I'm going to start slightly below them. http://www.earlywarningproject.com/2015/11/07/update-myanmar-elections

My impression from a visit to Myanmar nearly ten years ago was that it was a country with enormous potential if only the military repression didn't exist. Since then the country has opened up significantly, but there have been mass killings of Rohingya in the last year or so, while there are several conflicts between the army and various ethnic groups in remote parts of the country. The (hopefully) outgoing military regime has signed peace treaties with most of the ethnic groups, and a democratic government is likely to be more inclusive. The Rohingya problem remains, however, and Aung San Suu Kyi has been notably silent about them, though they expect her to be more helpful to them in power. A transition from military to civilian rule is tricky, especially in Myanmar where internal security will still be in the army's hands. It's quite possible that elements in the military fundamentally opposed to civilian rule may want to make the new government look bad, and even instigate new episodes. There is also the likelihood of repressed minorities revelling in greater freedom, which could end in conflict with more established groups. On the optimistic side, there have been no reports of anything on the scale of 1000 deaths per year, though a hard-line Buddhist monk's movement has been in the forefront of attacking Rohingya villages (this despite original Buddhist philosophy of peace, meditation and non-violence). I am aware of a persistent bias on my part towards optimism, but in this case I'm going to start significantly lower than the current consensus. To support my forecast, EWP's own subject expert pool predicts 10% today. http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools/106
My other reference is at 5%. https://thewideninglens.wordpress.com/2016/01/25/2016-mass-atrocity-forecasts/

I'm certainly not an expert (http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools/106), but I think starting low on this IFP is best. From the 'more info,' it's pretty clear that EWP wants to now about 'new episodes.' Meaning, "Karen" won't resolve this IFP. However, something involving the Rohingya would. Maybe I'm conflating in the wrong way, but the other IFP that's asking about Myanmar (re: government) leads me to believe that there might be some hope (?) for a reduction in violence within Myanmar. However, as the 'definitions' page makes clear, a mass killing perpetrated by a non-state actor would resolve the IFP.

I can't find any damn information about the number of Muslims killed in Burma in 2015. There's heaps about the number of refugees, or the number displaced, but practically nothing credible about the total number *killed* in that specific year. The most useful information I can find is a Jan 2015 LA Times article, which says that 240 Muslims have been killed in Myanmar over the last 2 years. (http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/jul/15/husain-counting-violent-muslim-deaths-country-2014/?page=all). So we'll work with a baseline of 120 killed per year, far lower than the 1000 needed for it to be defined as a mass killing. If the socio-political state of the country in 2014 continued into 2016, then I'd put the chance of a mass killing at about 5%. The number may very well increase for 2016, since  -Transitioning from a Junta to a democracy  (As has been happening in Myanmar since 2011) is an unstable process that has created large violent conflicts in other countries (Libya being the first example that comes to mind). I arbitrarily tripled the probability to 15% based on this. - One UN reporter claims that there is a "growing atmosphere of fear, distrust and hostility" in the country. This is weak anecdotal evidence that the situation is getting worse, so I'll bump it up 3%. If anyone can find some reliable data about what 2015 was like, please let me know.
It is possible to feel ambivalent about right on a mass murder question. These are among the most difficult for which to separate one's hopes from one's expectations.
